dataset.title: Individual and community flowering phenology, seed counts and pollinator visitation rates in shrub and open plots across Niwot Ridge, 2019 - 2021.

abstract.para: Climate-change induced alterations in environmental conditions in the alpine tundra has led to the expansion of woody shrubs, known as “shrubification.” Shrubification is thought to change microclimatic conditions, potentially leading to changes in plant community composition. Shrubification has been taking place at Niwot Ridge, a Long Term Ecological Research site nestled in the mountains of Colorado, for the past 40 years. Thus far, Niwot Ridge has seen some change in alpine plant communities due to shrubification, and changes in plant reproductive capacity and success could lead to future alterations of community composition.

One important aspect in plant reproductive success is the timing of flowering, known as flowering phenology. Flowering phenology is controlled partially by environmental conditions, and thus is somewhat plastic for many species. In the first part of my thesis, I explore how shrubification may be causing changes in flowering phenology for 21 different plant species in the alpine tundra community at Niwot Ridge. I conducted an observational study over three years, monitoring the number of flowers present in 54 pairs of shrub-influenced and open plots, totaling 108 plots. I found that there is no difference in the flowering phenology between open and shrub-influenced plots. There is a measurable difference in the number of flowers produced between shrub and open plots, with open plots having more flowers on average, This difference is likely due to there being fewer plants in shrub-influenced plots.

A second aspect explores shrub effects on the reproductive success of five different alpine species. In the field season of 2021, I took seeds from these five species from 12 pairs of shrub and open plots, totaling 24 plots. I counted and weighed the seeds to determine reproductive success; there was no difference in reproductive success between shrub and open plots.

description.para: Community-level flowering phenology was taken in the summers of 2019, 2020, and 2021 on 21 common alpine species. Common alpine species were selected in 2019 by determining which species had greater than 3 individuals in more than 10 plots (this was done through species composition assessments relatively early in the season).

Once per week, I visited all plots and recorded how many flowers were open (i.e. had reproductive parts showing, with petals still intact and on the flower) for each “common” species that was present in the plot. This continued throughout the flowering season.

Individual-level flowering phenology was taken in the summer of 2021. I selected 12 pairs of plots at random (equaling to 24 plots total), split evenly between north-facing and south-facing aspects and with and without shrubs, for a total 12 north (6 open and 6 shrub) and 12 south (6 open and 6 shrub)).

I marked up to 5 individuals of all of the “common” alpine species in each plot with a plastic toothpick that was distinguishable by both color and what shape was on top. Individuals were marked when they first started flowering, the toothpick color and top shape was recorded, and then that individual was tracked throughout the duration of the flowering season.

When a flower was first noticed, if it had all of its reproductive parts showing and was looking fresh (no petals falling off, anthers still had pollen on them, etc), it was entered as “new.” If a flower was beginning to show signs of senescence, but still had potential to attract pollinators or be pollinated itself (i.e. reproductive parts still showing, no obvious seeds being formed), it was entered as “old.” For plants that produce just one flower throughout the season (Tetraneuris acaulis, etc), the first time I noticed a flower was the time that I marked it as new. Plants that produced multiple individual flowers at once had their old and new flowers counted simultaneously. A flower was counted as ONE flower if it was on its own stem - this means that plants that produce spike or cluster flowers had each spike or cluster counting as one flower.
At the end of the flowering season, the total number of seed pods produced were counted as a proxy for how many flowers the plant produced over the duration of the season.
Pollinator observations were done in the summer of 2021. The same 12 pairs of plots that were used for individual flowering phenology were also used for pollinator observations.

Rough estimates of cloud cover and wind speed were recorded, along with what shrub number the observation took place at and the aspect of the shrub. The time that the observations were taken was recorded. All observations lasted 10 minutes. An observation was deemed applicable whenever a pollinator landed on an open flower (reproductive parts showing) within the plot for more than 1 second (i.e. looked like it meant to be there). Pollinator functional group (i.e. fly, bee, bombus, etc.) was recorded, No pollinators were collected. The plant the pollinator landed on (species specific) was recorded. If a pollinator landed on a plant, flew away for a minute, and then landed back on the plant, that was recorded as 2 separate observation. The time that a pollinator landed on a plant was recorded. Pollinator observations did not take place if it was raining or gusting over 40 MPH winds. Pollinator observations took place as long as there was one open flower in the plot.

Seeds were collected from 5 main species - GEUROS, KOBMYO, CARRUP, AREFEN, and MINOBT. Seeds were collected from the same plants that individual-level flowering phenology was done on. AREFEN stalks were bagged with organza bags before showing signs of senescence to ensure that early-flowered seeds would not be lost. Seed pods were collected in late August to late September. Seed pods were only collected when they were deemed “mature” - meaning they were brown and the seeds were ready to pop out. I visited each plot once per week throughout late August and late September to collect all seeds that were set. Seeds were put in a coin envelope that was taped at the corners to ensure that no seeds were lost. Envelopes were marked with the species, toothpick color, shrub number, plot number, number of inflorescences collected, and date of collection. Seeds were kept in the refrigerator in their respective envelopes until they were ready to be counted.

To count the seeds, I broke up the dried bud with my fingers. I then counted all viable seeds. Seeds were considered “viable” if they looked and felt plump compared to obviously aborted seeds (shriveled and small in appearance). I separated the seeds from the dried bud and counted each seed individually. The counts were recorded and the seeds placed back into their respective envelopes, corresponding to which specific plant the seeds came from. The seeds were then weighed as a group with a microbalance.

project.title: LTER: Long-term research on the dynamics of high-elevation ecosystems -- a framework for understanding ecological responsiveness to climate change

award.title: LTER: Long-term research on the dynamics of high-elevation ecosystems -- a framework for understanding ecological responsiveness to climate change

dataTable.entityDescription: Community-level flowering phenology for all 108 shrub and open plots at NWT, 2019-2021

dataTable.entityDescription: Individual-level flowering phenology for about 280 plants in 24 different shrub and open plots across NWT for 2021

Which shrub number the data corresponded to
Which aspect the plot was on
Which plant number was assigned (1-5) to this plant
Distance the plant was from the edge of the shrub (negative distances indicate plants under shrub)
Which toothpick color was assigned to this plant
How many flowers were counted of each type
